data.title: “The Love Bug” is a Sweet, Funny Ride From a Simpler Time
data.meta_description: Let’s pull up to the drive-in movie theatre and revisit a car that is the spawn of the devil himself. We’re throwing it way back with this review of 1968’s Disney comedy The Love Bug. It is the first…
data.text:
MOVIE NIGHTS WITH B

Beep, beep!

Let’s pull up to the drive-in movie theatre and revisit a car that is the spawn of the devil himself.

We’re throwing it way back with this review of 1968’s Disney comedy The Love Bug. It is the first of many movies about a little car determined to drive through life however the hell he wants to.

Protagonist Jim Douglas (Dean Jones) is a struggling race car driver who first sees Herbie in an upscale car showroom. Unable to afford anything in the store, he leaves only to find that this stubborn little car has followed him home.

Shenanigans ensue when he discovers that this tiny little car can pack a punch on the race track.

It is 2023, and self-driving cars still aren’t the norm on the roads.

But if they ever become mainstream, none of them will be as fun as Herbie.

Terrible Tech With a Timeless Message

Since the film came out when my parents were toddlers, I expected it to have cheesy special effects and cringy dialogue.
